title: Riot finally did it. They finally said FUCK YOU to all their players.

embed.description: With the introduction of dynamic queue, we alienated a portion of League's passionate player-base who believe a ranked competitive experience should be limited to a solo (or duo) endeavor. We agree dynamic queue standings don't reflect pure individual skill as well as a solo ladder, but they also don't inhibit competitive team experiences, and that's a trade-off we want to make.

body:
It took them 'til about halfway through the season but they finally dropped the bomb.

Solo queue is never coming back.

The ranked experience will never ever be returned to its former glory: a matchmaking system that worked.

GG solo players.

The boards and the Reddit community are not a random sample of League players. They are a subset of the population that comes to a forum to talk about the game, when most players don't ever do that. If you want the opinions of a random sample of League players, than you can't take it from a group that already has a significant difference from the general League population.

To get a representative sample, you take the sample randomly from the group itself. You don't take it from an already non representative subset of that group.
since when talking on a forum influence your opinion on Dynamic queue?

A more important question is "why do people come to the boards and post here?" The vast majority of League players don't and never will. Some players do come here and post, and that makes them different. That by itself is enough to say the group isn't representative. On that alone, I can say that taking the boards to represent the general League population is statistically invalid. People come here for quite a few reasons, and assuming those reasons are shared among the League population in general is invalid.

However, your question is important, and it does have an answer. When people go on the Boards, what do they see? Probably something like "Zed sucks" "Dynamic Queue sucks" "Fizz sucks", etc (I'm not taking any sides on these issues, I'm just using them as examples). These show up all the time, and almost more importantly, opinions disagreeing with them are almost universally downvoted and ridiculed. This means that the forum promotes a very homogenous view, and they are hostile to any views that are not the majority here.

Basically, if I actually thought that Dynamic Queue was a good thing or that Fizz was a well designed champion (and again, I'm just using these as examples), I'd maybe post here once before I got shouted down and insulted. If I said that I hated dynamic queue and that Fizz needs to be nerfed into oblivion, I'd get praise and people would agree with me. That encourages more posting. 

The boards are designed to only show one opinion. They are not favorable to representing the beliefs of everyone in League. They represent the members of the Boards. Nothing more. When the guy I responded to tried to use statistics to say that the boards represented the League population, he was dead wrong.

tl;dr: [This is nothing more than sampling bias.](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Selection_bias) The entire argument and conclusion is invalid because he has selected a nonrepresentative sample.

If you learned psychology, you know that the vocal minority is not even close to the content majority. The majority doesn't have anything to say because they don't need to say anything. They're satisfied, after all.

Hell, 90% of board + reddit users isn't even 10% of the entire League community. Even throwing out the consideration that the same people use both sites, at BEST you can say "10% of all League players are visibly upset." And that's not much at all.

the Accuracy of Surveys can be broken down to a measurement of "Margin of Error" and "confidence" (Also, I don't think Probability and stats are tought that in depth until the college level, so not everyone will know this.) "Margin of Error" is the % that it's off by. and the confidence is the probability that the actual value is within that margin of Error. 

I don't have the formula for you, but I looked up a calculator, (spoiler alert, your kinda right.) I think for a population of 10 million, you would only need to sample 2k to have a value that has a 99% confidence rating of being within a 3% margin of Error. So if out of 2000 people, 90% of them said they hated Dynamic Q. There's a 99% chance that the real value is between 87%-93%.

 There is just one problem where this experiment would break down. (Which could very well be the case.) Not everyone goes to boards. And the people who are on Boards, may not accurately represent the population. People on boards would tend to socialize more, and a likely more competitive if they are trying to stay on top of their game. Especially so With Game play and balance, as people are quick to address grievances. 

As a result, Boards does not offer the random sampling that is needed to make this experiment accurate. If you wanted random sampling, you would issue the survey within the client to say. 10,000 people who logged in.

"random pool"

You know, I'm pretty sure that a forum isn't a form of random sampling. In fact, I know for a fact that taking polls from preexisting groups like forums and calling them representative is a major fucking "DO NOT DO" for social psychology. Taking a small, voluntary group and calling it representative is the kind of thing that would laughed at in academia.

Taking the opinion of the Boards on anything and calling it representative of the League population is like polling members of the Republican National Committee and saying that their opinions are representative of the U.S. population. You've selected a group that doesn't represent the population.
